title: SPEC: Macro-to-grammar parameter binding
description:
## The Gap

Macros (articulation, persistence, emphasis.*) are 0‚Äì1 continuous values that "adjust high-level characteristics", but no contract specifies how these map to individual grammar parameters.

## Why It Matters

- SPEC_004 provides macro annotations with directionality descriptions (for LLM)
- But grammars have paramsSchema ‚Äî how do macro changes translate to param changes?
- Implementation teams must reverse-engineer intent from prose annotations
- Different grammars may interpret the same macro delta differently

## Current State

- `Preset.macros` defines articulation, persistence, emphasis.{melody,harmony,rhythm,timbre}
- `GrammarAnnotation.macroResponses` indicates responsiveness (strong/moderate/weak/none)
- `IGrammar.paramsSchema` exists but linkage to macros is undefined

## Questions to Answer

1. Is there a binding layer between macros and grammar params?
2. Do grammars receive macro values directly, or do they receive transformed params?
3. How does `macroResponses.responsiveness` translate to actual behavior?
4. Are sensitivity curves (linear, exponential) per-grammar or global?

## Relates To

- SPEC_004 (macro annotations)
- RFC_002 (Preset interface)
- synesthetica-30r (macro interpolation curves)

## Output

Either extend SPEC_004 or create a new spec defining the macro ‚Üí grammar param binding contract.

title: P0: Canvas2D renderer
description:
Minimal renderer that draws SceneFrame entities to canvas.

- Canvas2D (not WebGL)
- Draw particles as circles
- Handle color, size, opacity from entity style
- No effects or post-processing

title: Should Style be called VisualGrammar?
close_reason: Resolved. Renamed Style ‚Üí Grammar throughout codebase. Annotations include aliases field for user-facing synonyms (style, look, effect). See SPEC_004.

title: Define macro interpolation curves
description: Macros are 0-1 continuous values but how they map to internal parameters (linear, exponential, stepped) is not defined. Low priority for v0.

title: Decide platform and rendering target for v0
description:
The PRD defers platform assumptions, but practical development requires a decision.

Options:
1. Browser-first: Web Audio API + Web MIDI API + Canvas/WebGL
2. Native-first: Electron + Node MIDI libraries + native rendering
3. Hybrid: Core logic portable, adapters platform-specific

Considerations:
- Browser has better MIDI support than commonly assumed (Web MIDI API)
- Audio input in browser requires user permission flow
- WebGL gives good rendering performance
- Native gives lower latency but more setup friction

Output: Document platform decision in PRD.md under 'Platform assumptions'. This unblocks adapter and renderer implementation.
close_reason: Platform decision documented in PRD.md: Browser-first (Web MIDI + Web Audio + WebGL), with audio file input for testing. Native deferred to post-v0.

title: SPEC: Audio adapter CMS contract
description:
## The Gap

Audio adapter is referenced in PRD and planned for Phase 2, but no interface specifies how audio evidence maps to CMS fields.

## Why It Matters

- Can't implement audio support without this contract
- Invariants I4/I5 assume audio adapters produce uncertain CMS
- Phase 2 (synesthetica-jes) depends on this foundation
- synesthetica-y7q (Meyda evaluation) needs target contract to evaluate against

## Current State

- ISourceAdapter.nextFrame(): CMSFrame is generic
- CMS types support confidence/provenance for uncertainty
- No spec for pitch-class distribution format from audio
- No spec for beat detection output or chord inference confidence

## Questions to Answer

1. How are pitch-class distributions represented? (DistributionSignal?)
2. What confidence thresholds distinguish "heard C" from "maybe C"?
3. How does beat detection produce Beat events vs BeatPhase signals?
4. What's the expected latency profile for audio analysis?

## Relates To

- PRD (audio input requirement)
- SPEC_003 (invariants I1-I5)
- synesthetica-y7q (Meyda evaluation)
- RFC_002 (CMS specification)

## Output

New spec (SPEC_009?) defining AudioAdapterV0 contract and CMS output format for audio.

title: P0: Build-time annotation validation
description:
Validate annotations at build time per SPEC_004.

## Checks
- Grammar `id` must be unique
- Grammar `aliases` should not conflict across grammars  
- `illustrates` values must be valid MusicalConcept
- `traits` values must be valid VisualTrait
- Macro annotations must exist for all macros in Preset.macros schema

## Implementation
- TypeScript compiler plugin, or
- Build script that validates annotation files
- CI integration

## On failure
- Build fails with clear error message identifying the violation

title: SPEC: Router/stabilizer interaction and per-part state
description:
## The Gap

RFC_003 introduces routing by PartId, SPEC_006 defines stateful stabilizers, but their interaction is ambiguous.

## Why It Matters

- Should stabilizers run before or after routing?
- Do stabilizers maintain per-part state or global state?
- Can stabilizers aggregate across parts (ensemble tension)?
- Some signals (global activity) conceptually span parts

## Current State

- IRouter.route(frame) ‚Üí Map<PartId, CMSFrame>
- IStabilizer has init/dispose/apply/reset lifecycle
- SPEC_008 shows "for each part, run stabilizers" but doesn't clarify instantiation
- CMS events have part: PartId but control signals may be global

## Questions to Answer

1. Are stabilizers instantiated per-part or singleton?
2. If per-part, when are new stabilizer instances created?
3. Can a stabilizer read signals from other parts?
4. What's the ordering: route then stabilize, or stabilize then route?

## Relates To

- RFC_003 (parts and routing)
- SPEC_006 (stabilizer lifecycle)
- SPEC_008 (pipeline orchestration)

## Output

Additions to SPEC_006 or SPEC_008 clarifying stabilizer instantiation and data access scope.

title: Define Preset storage and lifecycle
description:
Preset lifecycle is unspecified:
- How are presets created, saved, edited?
- Where are they stored? (localStorage, JSON files, DB)
- Who validates them against the schema?
- How do built-in vs user presets coexist?

Output:
1. Document preset storage format and location
2. Add validation helpers or schema to packages/contracts
3. Define the distinction between builtin/user presets
4. Amend RFC 002 or create SPEC for preset management
close_reason: Preset storage defined in SPEC_001_preset_storage.md. Contracts added to packages/contracts/config/preset.ts: PresetSource, PresetMeta, ValidationResult, IPresetCatalog. localStorage for v0, interface abstracts for future migration.

title: SPEC: Grammar registration and discovery mechanism
description:
## The Gap

Grammars are referenced by ID in presets, but no contract specifies how grammars are discovered, registered, or validated at runtime.

## Why It Matters

- How does the engine know which grammars are available?
- What happens when a preset references a non-existent grammar?
- How do contributors add grammars without modifying core code?
- Open/closed principle requires a discovery mechanism

## Current State

- Preset.grammars references grammarId strings
- IGrammar interface exists but no IGrammarRegistry
- synesthetica-d53 calls for contribution guide but not the registry contract
- synesthetica-5l9 validates annotations but not grammar existence

## Questions to Answer

1. Is there an IGrammarRegistry interface?
2. How are grammars discovered (import map? directory scan? explicit registration?)
3. What validation runs at grammar load time?
4. What diagnostic is emitted for missing grammar references?

## Relates To

- RFC_002 (grammar API)
- synesthetica-d53 (contribution guide)
- synesthetica-5l9 (annotation validation)

## Output

New interface (IGrammarRegistry) and additions to SPEC_008 or a new spec.

title: P0: Golden test infrastructure
description:
Test harness for rulesets and grammars.

- CMS fixtures (JSON) ‚Üí expected IntentFrame
- IntentFrame sequences ‚Üí expected entity snapshots
- Deterministic via rngSeed
- Snapshot comparison utilities

title: Define frame timing and clock semantics
description:
The timing model is underspecified.

Questions to resolve:
- What drives the frame clock? Pull-based (renderer requests) or push-based (adapters emit)?
- What happens when audio and MIDI have different latencies?
- What epoch are Ms timestamps relative to?
- How is frame synchronization handled across multiple sources?

Output: Add timing/clock types to packages/contracts/core. Document frame semantics in a new SPEC or amend RFC 002.
close_reason: Resolved in SPEC_005_frame_timing_and_clock.md. Decisions: pull-based clock, session-relative timestamps, accept differing latencies for v0, per-part CMS (not consolidated). Ensemble mode deferred to synesthetica-h09.

title: Define entity budget and performance constraints
description: PRD mentions 60fps target / 30fps fallback but no entity limits or constraint system is specified. Need to define what limits entity count and how grammars handle overload.

title: Clarify Ruleset statefulness requirements
description:
IRuleset.map(frame: CMSFrame): IntentFrame is currently stateless, but some mappings need history:
- 'Tension' might depend on harmonic trajectory over several beats
- Beat phase detection might need memory
- Phrase-level dynamics require lookback

Questions to resolve:
- Should rulesets be allowed internal state?
- Or should history be a stabilizer concern (stabilizers build up state, rulesets remain pure)?
- If stateful, what's the reset/init contract?

Output: Amend IRuleset interface in packages/contracts/pipeline/interfaces.ts if needed. Document the decision in RFC 002 or a new ADR.
close_reason: Resolved in SPEC_006. Decision: Rulesets remain pure/stateless. Stabilizers are explicitly stateful with init/dispose/reset lifecycle. Temporal reasoning (tension, beat phase, phrase position) belongs in stabilizers as derived signals.

title: SPEC: Ruleset fallback behavior and confidence gating
description:
## The Gap

IRuleset.map(frame: CMSFrame): IntentFrame is minimal. No guidance on how rulesets handle incomplete/uncertain musical data.

## Why It Matters

- What if CMS has no chord info (audio inference failed)?
- How should ruleset weight intents when signals are missing?
- Should rulesets emit all intent types every frame, or only meaningful ones?
- No confidence thresholds or gating rules are specified

## Current State

- CMSFrame has events, controls, distributions ‚Äî all optional/sparse
- IntentFrame has intents array and uncertainty scalar
- Invariant I5: "Confidence affects rendering stability, not meaning"
- But no guidance on how rulesets should implement this

## Questions to Answer

1. What's the fallback behavior when expected CMS signals are absent?
2. Are there confidence thresholds below which signals are ignored?
3. Must rulesets emit all four intent types (palette, motion, texture, shape)?
4. How does the ruleset compute IntentFrame.uncertainty?

## Relates To

- SPEC_003 (invariants I1-I5)
- RFC_002 (ruleset role)
- SPEC_007 (graceful degradation)

## Output

Additions to RFC_002 or a new spec documenting ruleset semantics for edge cases.

title: P0: Project structure and build setup
P0: Identity compositor
description: Single-part compositor that passes through the scene unchanged.

title: Document grammar contribution guide (open/closed pattern)
description:
Define how contributors (human or LLM) add new grammars to the system while adhering to the open/closed principle.

## Goals
- Grammars are open for extension (new grammars can be added)
- Core system is closed for modification (adding a grammar doesn't change pipeline code)
- Clear contract that guides LLM-driven grammar development

## Should cover
1. **Grammar contract**: What IGrammar implementations must provide
2. **Annotation requirements**: Required GrammarAnnotation fields for LLM discoverability
3. **Registration pattern**: How grammars are discovered/registered without modifying core
4. **Testing requirements**: What tests a grammar must pass before inclusion
5. **File/folder conventions**: Where grammar code and annotations live
6. **Example template**: A minimal grammar that serves as a starting point

## Constraints
- Grammars MUST NOT compute musical semantics (I4)
- Grammars MUST NOT read other parts (I7)
- Grammars receive IntentFrame, emit SceneFrame
- All entities must be tagged with the grammar's PartId

## Evolution policy
This guide may be iterated as we learn. Any changes MUST be back-ported to all existing grammars to maintain consistency. The guide is a living document during Phase 1.

## Output
A SPEC or guide document that an LLM could follow to implement a new grammar from scratch.

Registration and Motif are obtuse jargon. Rename to clearer terms:

title: Ensemble mode: cross-part musical interpretation
description:
## Context

During frame timing design (SPEC_005), we identified a tension between:
- **Per-part interpretation** (current design): Each part gets independent musical interpretation. Essential for ear training where you need to compare reference vs. attempt.
- **Ensemble interpretation** (deferred): Multiple sources contribute to a single unified musical interpretation (e.g., Part 1's C-E-G + Part 2's E-G-B = Cmaj7).

## Why Deferred

Per-part is correct for v0's ear training focus. Ensemble mode would:
- Require a fusion step upstream of CMS generation
- Lose per-part attribution at the CMS level
- Violate the current I3 invariant if done at the wrong layer

## Architectural Insight

If implemented, ensemble mode would need:
1. Adapters emit an intermediate "raw musical evidence" format
2. A fusion step merges evidence from multiple sources
3. CMS is generated from the fused evidence
4. A synthetic PartId (e.g., "ensemble") for the fused stream

This is a fundamentally different mode of operation, not something achievable by merging at the compositor level (which can only blend visuals, not re-interpret musical meaning).

## When to Revisit

- When supporting live ensemble performance visualization
- When users want unified harmonic analysis across multiple players
- Not needed for single-player ear training scenarios

title: Define error and diagnostic model
description:
No error handling contract exists. What happens when:
- An adapter fails to parse input?
- A motif throws during update?
- The LLM produces an invalid ControlOp?
- A registration references a non-existent motif?

Output: Add Diagnostic, PipelineError, and ValidationResult types to packages/contracts. Define error propagation semantics (fail-fast vs graceful degradation per component).

title: P1: Ruleset iteration (find what works)
description:
Exploratory work on rulesets. This is creative, not mechanical.

- Experiment with CMS ‚Üí Intent mappings

- Build golden tests as we go

This task stays open during exploration. Close when we have confidence.

title: SPEC: Entity position and canvas coordinate system
description:
## The Gap

Entity.position is Vec2, GrammarContext has canvasSize, but the coordinate system is never defined.

## Why It Matters

- Grammars spawn entities with positions ‚Äî what's the reference frame?
- Layout transforms apply to positions ‚Äî what order? What semantics?
- Different renderers (Canvas2D, WebGL) have different conventions
- Multi-part rendering coordination requires shared coordinate semantics

## Current State

- Entity.position?: Vec2 (x, y numbers, no units specified)
- GrammarContext.canvasSize: { width, height } ‚Äî pixels? normalized?
- LayoutPolicy.region: left/right/top/bottom/center/full ‚Äî transform behavior undefined
- No origin convention (top-left? center? bottom-left?)

## Questions to Answer

1. What coordinate system do grammars emit positions in? (0‚Äì1 normalized? pixels?)
2. Where is the origin? (canvas top-left? center? part-local?)
3. How do layout policies transform grammar-generated positions?
4. How does scaling work for responsive canvas resize?

## Relates To

- RFC_002 (grammar context)
- RFC_003 (layout policies)
- SPEC_008 (compositor)

## Output

Additions to RFC_002 and RFC_003 defining coordinate conventions and transform order.

title: P1: Grammar iteration (build vocabulary)
description:
Exploratory work on grammars. Build a vocabulary of visual treatments.

Target: at least 3 distinct grammars with different characters:
- Something discrete/transient (particles, stars)
- Something continuous/flowing (trails, fields)
- Something structural (chords, harmony visualization)

Document macro responses as we learn them.

title: SPEC: Grammar composition and conflict resolution
description:
## The Problem

Multiple active grammars may respond to the same intents differently. How do we combine their outputs?

Current implicit model: grammars are additive (each emits entities, compositor merges).

### Data flow context
```
CMS ‚Üí Ruleset ‚Üí IntentFrame ‚Üí Grammar(s) ‚Üí SceneFrame ‚Üí Renderer
```

- Ruleset interprets CMS into musical intents (PaletteIntent, MotionIntent, TextureIntent, ShapeIntent)
- Each intent carries confidence
- Multiple grammars receive the SAME IntentFrame
- Each grammar emits entities to a SceneFrame
- Compositor merges SceneFrames (concat + layout + blending)

### Where this breaks down

1. **Conflicting motion**: Grammar A interprets MotionIntent.flow as "drift left", Grammar B as "drift right"
2. **Macro confusion**: User says "emphasise rhythm" ‚Äî macroResponses guide which grammars to adjust, but they may respond in incompatible ways
3. **Visual chaos**: Two "reactive" grammars both responding to onsets = doubled visual noise
4. **Coherence**: User expects a unified visual response, not independent layers doing their own thing

### Concrete example

Active grammars: Starfield (discrete, transient) + Rain (continuous, persistent)

User plays a chord. Both grammars receive the same IntentFrame:
- Starfield spawns burst of particles
- Rain increases field density

Is this composition? Or conflict? Depends on the grammars' traits and whether they're designed to complement.

## Questions to answer

1. **Are grammars truly independent?**
   - Do they share any state or negotiate?
   - Can one grammar suppress or modify another?
   - Should grammars be aware of what other grammars are active?

2. **What is the composition model?**
   - Pure entity concatenation (current)?
   - Priority/layering with masking?
   - Domain-based routing (grammar A handles motion, B handles texture)?
   - Grammars declare "slots" they fill?

3. **How do macros interact with multiple grammars?**
   - Each grammar interprets macros independently via paramsSchema?
   - macroResponses annotations guide which grammars to adjust?
   - Some macros are "global" vs "per-grammar"?
   - LLM uses macroResponses to make coherent choices?

4. **What happens on conflict?**
   - Both emit (visual chaos)?
   - One wins (priority)?
   - They blend (how?)?
   - It's a design error (grammars shouldn't conflict)?

5. **Role of presets**
   - Do presets guarantee coherent grammar combinations?
   - Is "these grammars work together" part of preset design?
   - Should presets declare grammar relationships?

## Relevant contracts

- `IGrammar.update(input: IntentFrame, previous: SceneFrame | null): SceneFrame`
- `ICompositor.compose(frames: SceneFrame[]): SceneFrame`
- `GrammarAnnotation.traits` ‚Äî could indicate compatibility
- `GrammarAnnotation.macroResponses` ‚Äî how grammar responds to macros
- `Preset.grammars` ‚Äî list of grammars with enabled/params/priority

## Approaches to evaluate

### 1. Additive (status quo)
- Document when it works and when it doesn't
- Rely on preset curation to avoid conflicts
- Traits annotations help LLM avoid bad combinations
- Simple, but pushes complexity to users/LLM

### 2. Priority-based layering
- Grammars have explicit priority in preset
- Higher-priority grammar's entities render on top
- Doesn't solve semantic conflict, only visual layering

### 3. Domain declarations
- Grammar declares which intent channels it consumes
- `consumes: ["motion", "palette"]` vs `consumes: ["texture"]`
- Compositor routes accordingly
- Conflict = build-time warning
- Limits expressiveness

### 4. Slot-based composition
- Define visual "slots" (background field, mid particles, foreground glyphs)
- Each grammar fills specific slots
- Compositor arranges slots
- More structured, less flexible

### 5. Pre-grammar intent arbitration
- Intents are merged/arbitrated before reaching grammars
- Single "negotiated" IntentFrame per part
- Grammars see consistent signals
- Loses per-grammar character

## Phase 0 avoidance

Phase 0 uses a single grammar, so this is not blocking. But Phase 1 grammar iteration will hit this immediately when combining grammars.

## Output

Either a SPEC or additions to SPEC_004/SPEC_008 clarifying:
1. Grammar composition semantics
2. Conflict detection/resolution strategy
3. How presets encode grammar compatibility
4. How macroResponses guide multi-grammar adjustment

title: Define derived signals schema for stabilizers
description: SPEC_006 defers defining the schema for derived signals that stabilizers add to CMSFrame (e.g., harmonicTension, beatPhase, phrasePosition). Need to define what signals exist and their types.

title: SPEC: Control operation validation error format
description:
## The Gap

ControlOpResult includes ValidationError with field/reason/hint, but the format and completeness of feedback are undefined.

## Why It Matters

- LLM relies on errors to diagnose and fix bad commands
- Incomplete error context forces guessing or random retry
- No examples or error message grammar is provided
- Recovery quality depends on error quality

## Current State

- ValidationError: { field, reason, hint? }
- ControlOpResult: { success, errors?, diagnostics? }
- SPEC_007 defines the types but not content standards

## Questions to Answer

1. What's the format for field paths? (e.g., "macros.emphasis.rhythm")
2. Should reason be machine-readable or prose?
3. What constitutes a good hint for LLM recovery?
4. Are there standard error codes or categories?

## Relates To

- SPEC_007 (validation errors)
- RFC_004 (LLM mediation)

## Output

Additions to SPEC_007 with examples and format guidelines for validation errors.

title: SPEC: Macro persistence across preset changes
description:
## The Gap

When switching presets, it's unclear whether macro values are preserved, reset, or interpolated.

## Why It Matters

- User expectations differ: "keep my rhythm emphasis" vs "reset to preset defaults"
- Interaction model doesn't specify user intent for transitions
- LLM has no guidance on whether to explicitly reset macros
- Affects speech patterns like "use jazz mode but keep the rhythm emphasis"

## Current State

- Preset.macros defines default values
- ControlOp.applyPreset applies a preset
- ControlOp.setMacro patches macros independently
- No spec defines transition semantics

## Questions to Answer

1. Does applyPreset reset all macros to preset defaults?
2. Can users opt to preserve macro values across preset changes?
3. Should macro transitions be interpolated (smooth) or instant?
4. Is this configurable per-preset or global?

## Relates To

- RFC_001 (interaction model)
- SPEC_004 (macros)
- synesthetica-30r (macro interpolation)

## Output

Additions to SPEC_004 or RFC_001 defining preset transition semantics for macros.

title: Implement diagnostic logging infrastructure
description:
## Context

SPEC_007 requires that all diagnostics are logged regardless of visual indication. Need to implement the logging infrastructure.

## Requirements

- All Diagnostic emissions logged to console and/or file
- Minimum log format: [timestamp] [category] [severity] message
- Include source and partId when available
- Support structured logging (JSON) for easier parsing
- Consider log levels for filtering

## Reference

See SPEC_007_error_and_diagnostic_model.md "Logging Requirements" section.

## Acceptance

- Diagnostics from all categories are logged
- Log format is consistent and parseable
- Log output is configurable (console, file, both)

title: Update PRD to reflect RFC proposals
description:
The PRD is sparse and doesn't reflect the detailed requirements that have emerged from the RFCs.

Update PRD to include:
- Functional requirements from RFC 002 (CMS, intents, motifs, registrations)
- Interaction model from RFC 001 (postures, commitment verbs, layers)
- Multi-instrument support from RFC 003 (parts, routing, layout)
- LLM mediation from RFC 004 (speech control, annotations)

Keep it product-focused (what the system does for users), not implementation-focused (how it works internally).
close_reason: PRD updated with functional requirements from all RFCs: input processing, visual output, parts/routing, registrations, interaction model, speech control, and user journeys.

title: Define preset export/import JSON schema
description: SPEC_001 mentions exportUser()/importUser(json) but no JSON schema is defined for the export format. Low priority for v0.

title: SPEC: Entity lifecycle and decay semantics
description:
## The Gap

Entity has `life?: { ttlMs: Ms; ageMs: Ms }` but decay/removal semantics are never specified.

## Why It Matters

- Who manages entity decay ‚Äî grammar or compositor?
- Is ttl advisory or enforced?
- How does persistence macro map to ttl values?
- Without clarity, entity budgets (synesthetica-9f3) are uncontrollable

## Current State

- Entity.life is optional with ttlMs and ageMs
- Compositor composes SceneFrames but role in lifecycle is unclear
- Grammars receive `previous: SceneFrame | null` ‚Äî can see old entities
- No spec defines who increments ageMs or removes expired entities

## Questions to Answer

1. Does the compositor enforce ttl, or is it grammar responsibility?
2. What happens when ageMs >= ttlMs? Immediate removal? Fade?
3. How does persistence macro (0=ephemeral, 1=lingering) affect ttl?
4. Can entities be explicitly killed by grammars, or only via ttl?

## Relates To

- SPEC_008 (compositor responsibilities)
- RFC_002 (entity model)
- synesthetica-9f3 (entity budget)

## Output

Additions to SPEC_008 or RFC_002 defining entity lifecycle stages and decay ownership.

title: Define stabilizer ordering strategy
description: SPEC_006 defers stabilizer ordering/composition. When multiple stabilizers run, their order may matter (e.g., beat detection before phrase detection). Need to define ordering strategy.

title: Specify try/keep/discard lifecycle and session state
description:
RFC 001 introduces commitment verbs (try, keep, discard, queue) but there's no contract surface for this.

Questions to resolve:
- What is the representation of a 'trial' state?
- Can you have nested trials?
- How does 'discard' know what to revert to?
- What is a Checkpoint?

Output: Add SessionState, Checkpoint, and Trial types to packages/contracts. Amend RFC 001 or create a new RFC section specifying the lifecycle semantics.
close_reason: Deferred to LLM. The engine provides preset CRUD (IPresetCatalog); try/keep/discard semantics are left to the user‚ÜîLLM conversation, not specified by the engine.

title: P0: Pipeline orchestrator
description:
Implement IPipeline.requestFrame() - the central coordinator.

- Wire adapter ‚Üí stabilizer ‚Üí ruleset ‚Üí grammar ‚Üí compositor
- Single part only (no routing yet)
- Pull-based frame model per SPEC_005/SPEC_008

title: SPEC: PartSelector resolution and error handling
description:
## The Gap

PartSelector supports label/mostActive/all modes, but resolution logic and failure behavior are unspecified.

## Why It Matters

- Control op targeting "guitar" fails if no part has that label
- mostActive returns null when no recent activity
- LLM has no feedback to disambiguate failed resolution
- Speech patterns ("this is the guitar") depend on reliable deictic resolution

## Current State

- PartSelector: partId | label | mostActive | all
- IActivityTracker.getMostActive(windowMs) can return null
- PartRegistry.setLabel() exists but no query for "does label exist?"
- SPEC_007 mentions control diagnostics but not selector resolution

## Questions to Answer

1. What diagnostic is emitted when label resolution fails?
2. What happens when mostActive returns null? No-op? Error?
3. Should LLM query available parts/labels before issuing ops?
4. Is there a "best effort" mode vs "strict" mode?

## Relates To

- RFC_004 (LLM mediation)
- SPEC_007 (control diagnostics)
- RFC_003 (part registry)

## Output

Additions to SPEC_007 or RFC_003 defining selector resolution semantics and error reporting.

title: Implement diagnostic visual indicator in renderer
description:
## Context

SPEC_007 recommends that renderers display visual indicators for active diagnostics. This is a user experience feature to surface issues without requiring log inspection.

## Requirements

- Display category-specific icons in top-right corner (or configurable location)
- Categories: input (üîå), stabilizer (‚öôÔ∏è), grammar (üé®), control (üéõÔ∏è)
- Transient diagnostics: flash briefly then fade
- Sticky diagnostics: persist until condition clears
- Multiple diagnostics: show count badge or stack icons

## Reference

See SPEC_007_error_and_diagnostic_model.md "Visual Indicator" section.

## Acceptance

- Renderer displays appropriate icon when diagnostics are present in SceneFrame

title: SPEC: Preset versioning and backward compatibility
description:
## The Gap

No versioning scheme exists for presets ‚Äî if a grammar's parameter schema changes, existing saved presets break silently.

## Why It Matters

- Users accumulate presets over time
- Breaking changes orphan saved configurations
- No migration semantics or compatibility markers exist
- Imports from other users may reference unknown grammars

## Current State

- PresetMeta has id, name, source, timestamps ‚Äî no version
- IPresetCatalog.importUser validates but behavior for unknowns is undefined
- synesthetica-r0y notes JSON schema gap
- No deprecation policy for grammars/macros

## Questions to Answer

1. Should presets have version numbers?
2. What's the migration strategy for incompatible presets?
3. How are unknown grammar references handled?
4. Should presets declare minimum engine version?

## Relates To

- SPEC_001 (preset storage)
- synesthetica-r0y (export/import schema)

## Output

Additions to SPEC_001 defining preset versioning, compatibility markers, and migration rules.

title: P2: Evaluate Meyda.js for audio adapter
description:
Evaluate whether Meyda.js (https://meyda.js.org/) is suitable for the audio MIR pipeline.

## What Meyda provides
- Real-time audio feature extraction in browser
- Spectral features (centroid, rolloff, flatness, etc.)
- Perceptual features (loudness, RMS)
- Chroma / pitch class distribution

## Questions to answer
- Does it provide pitch-class distributions with confidence?
- Can it detect beats/onsets?
- What's the latency profile?
- Does it fit our CMSFrame model?

## Alternatives to consider
- Essentia.js
- Custom Web Audio API implementation
- Combination approach

This is Phase 2 work ‚Äî we need the pipeline proven with MIDI first.

title: P0: Minimal ruleset (pitch‚Üíhue, velocity‚Üíbrightness)
description:
First ruleset implementation. Minimal but real.

- pitch-class ‚Üí hue (using pcToHue invariant)
- velocity ‚Üí brightness
- Produces PaletteIntent and basic MotionIntent
- No chord/beat/phrase handling yet

title: Design Configuration Service and composite storage
description:
User-authored presets (named configurations like 'matching fireworks') need persistent storage, but the LLM shouldn't own this.

Proposed approach:
- LLM proposes names/checkpoints via bounded ControlOps
- A Configuration Service owns the catalog and validates all writes
- User presets stored as first-class catalog entries

New types needed:
- UserPreset (snapshot of style selection + macro values + patches)
- Checkpoint (trial state for undo/discard)
- IConfigurationService interface

Storage for v0: localStorage in browser

Output:
1. Add checkpoint and user preset types to packages/contracts/config/
2. Extend ControlOps with checkpoint operations
3. Add IConfigurationService to packages/contracts/pipeline/
4. Create RFC or SPEC documenting the persistence model
close_reason: Complete. IPresetCatalog provides CRUD for presets (list, get, save, delete, import/export). Types in packages/contracts/config/preset.ts, documented in SPEC_001.

title: [EPIC] Phase 1: Ruleset & Grammar Exploration
description:
